title-group.article-title: Accounting for Advertising as a Barrier to Entry

abstract.p: This paper examines two questions. (1) Is the correlation between advertising intensity and profit rates explainable in terms of accounting practices? (2) Does advertising create barriers to entry? It might be thought that the answer to 1 determines the answer to 2, but this is not so because accounting practices can be distortive of the investment-like quality of advertising whether or not advertising gives rise to entry barriers. The answer to question 1 is provided by taking note of the fact that accounting practices should not be equally distortive in all situations, or even that they should be distortive in the same direction. The answer to 2 is obtained through study of intertemporal price stability. The evidence indicates a yes answer to 1 and a no answer to 2.
